SENT.plain: Bilateral facial nerve palsy is relatively uncommon and may occur in association with a variety of neurological, infectious, neoplastic or degenerative disorders
Presentation is made of 4 cases of bilateral facial diplegia due to a refractory anemia with excess of blasts, a Lyme disease and a tuberculoid leprosy
In one of these patients the cause of bilateral seventh-nerve palsy was unknown (Bell's palsy)
Facial palsy returned to normal after treatment with steroids in 3 patients
The patient with myelodysplastic syndrome did not show any improvement and died 6 months after diagnosis
